Author: IIoT#4707
Content:
📢 Important Update: ProveIt! 2025 EU Conference Cancellation 📢

Dear ProveIt! Community,

We regret to announce that due to the logistical challenges of coordinating two concurrent conferences in the US and the EU within six months, we have made the difficult decision to cancel the EU portion of ProveIt! 2025. We understand this news may be disappointing and we sincerely apologize for any inconvenience this may cause. We came to this difficult decision in the best interest of providing the best experience for our audience and vendors.

While our U.S. team and EU partners could likely pull off the concurrent shows, in Thursday's team meeting, Walker asked the team, "If we continue with both… will we have the same quality in the EU as we will provide in the U.S.?" The team reluctantly conceded this was not possible, and Walker made the decision to put all of the team’s efforts into the Dallas venue.

What’s Next?
Ticket Options: We invite our EU attendees to apply the cost of their EU ticket purchase towards a US ticket for the Dallas conference from February 18-20, 2025. Alternatively, full refunds are available for those who cannot attend the Dallas event.

Future Plans: We are committed to bringing ProveIt! to Europe in the future and will provide updates as soon as possible.

We appreciate your understanding and continued support. For any questions or concerns, please contact us at contact@proveitconference.com.

Stay connected for more updates, and we look forward to seeing you at ProveIt! 2025 in Dallas!

Sincerely,
The 4.0 Solutions and ProveIt! Conference Teams

Author: vatsalshah
Content:
I think you should really give Dell NativeEdge a try. You will be impressed with the depth of the product. Dell NativeEdge is probably one of the missing pieces of the puzzle for scaling & managing plant applications. 

We are currently engaged in a couple of large projects with Dell. My point of view -  

1. Day 0: When pre-provisioning the hardware (rugged or server0, they ensure the root of trust at the factory level before shipping it to customers. 
2. Day 0 : They load hypervisor / native edge directly as well as pre-load apps if needed.
3. At Day 1 : They provided the best way to orchestrate complex applications—VM or containerized. It's a form-based system that provides the whole app.
4. Day 2 : Full cycle of management, update, rollback, security, alerts, logs and more. 
5. Day 2 : They take care of complex app-to-app orchestration.
6. Beyond Day 30 : Take the same templates and instantly replicate the whole infra to many sites.

Take Litmus Edge for Industrial DataOps, Clarority for cyber security, PAN for firewall, Litmus UNS and Grafana for visualization - they can orchestrate the whole thing in 1 click. 

You can consider most of the above as IT things, but they are also essential for OT app to scale/replicate.

Content:
Some of the legacy solutions have some degree of IBM iSeries (AS/400) support. Some of them have had minor updates within recent years. Or, the legacy installation base is still being supported with patches and service contracts.

Infor LN (ex-Baan) is x86 architecture, but quite a few of the other acquired solutions in Infor's portfolio run on iSeries such as XA (ex-MAPICS), LX (ex-BPCS), and System21. As recent as ~2019, I was encountering steel and automotive suppliers running these systems and would need to integrate with them. Most were in the long process of migrating off of them. Occasionally, I would encounter automotive OEMs with a random one-off mainframe apps. Stellantis still manages logistics of its dunnage/containers with some ancient app like this.

The previous generation of Oracle JDE, JD Edwards World, is still technically supported and running on IBM iSeries.

Apparently, IBM still have some business units for supporting this infrastructure. I would imagine some of the banks and transportation companies still have some crazy backend systems that depend on it. AWS RDS added IBM DB2 support last year. So, someone, somewhere still is running this stuff.

Content:
Since I know the group that failed as I was in the audience and I know the presenter personally I’ll shed some light on it. 

It was BEET. Their platform is built around cycle time analysis at a very granular level. When I was at Dana we used their solution on a line we had during commissioning and startup. It requires a significant amount of PLC logic because it captures the millisecond cycle time of every step of an operation. Things like valves firing, movements, pallet stops, etc. 

David, who was the presenter, is the CTO of the company. I think he saw an opportunity to sponsor something and didn’t realize the type of conference this was, and maybe his business lead hung him out to dry a bit there. 

I will say that I talked to him after and he mentioned that there were two very large global automotive companies that came to talk to him after and were very impressed with his demo.

Author: r.pop
Content: So while he didn’t fulfill the brief, there were some people in the community that saw value in his solution.

Author: _dyland
Content:
A couple things, first, something I have been preaching outside of this discord for years (something I drill into all of my Controls Engineers) is that "good" PLC programs should be written with these hooks in mind from the start. A program that is architected, designed, documented, and written well should not take more than a few minutes to extend for applications like this. 

But that conveniently ignores brownfield and thousands of engineers that I can not reach with that message. 

From there, on BEETs side of things, how can they get the raw data and contextualize it in their software? Or work with a partner who can? Rather than relying on the actual event could there be a logic engine that takes the raw event, even from the IO points and derives the events that matter to the use case?

Basically, how can they move the reliance of editing PLC code into their platform?

Maybe this is where the UNS comes in?

This comes up often. The root cause of it is when orgs start with data producers and connecting to them. They realize months or years later that they don't have a data infrastructure around enabling data consumers. By working backwards from use cases, it "threads" a companies unique culture into an architecture.

Author: markyfreeds
Content:
i don't have a working definition of "monolith" but i have examples that help me understand and question its meaning. 

For example, i think we could all agree pick-your-erp is a monolith. why? because in order to deploy it you need to structure your reality within a defined framework, and every element of the framework must be filled in before you can fire it up. i can't place orders without products, can't release them without a routing, and down the rabbit hole until youve (inaccurately) mapped your world into another system's world view.

I've also built applications in Tulip and other systems that operate similarly, i have to feed the system my reality into conform to the way the system needs to operate it. smaller pieces than an erp, but smells like a monolith. why? probably because I've limited the user into conforming into my view of the world, mandating they understand the concepts ive come up with.

But then i've built applications in Tulip, which has the potential to be operated in a highly composable way (and is how we recommend using it), where i allow users to create and solve problems and create their world view.. this works well for small scoped problems.  once you connect the solutions together you have higher orders of logic or standards that start smelling like a monolith.... now you can abstract that logic into other end user categories (like solution architects) but then, is the end user making the highly-composable app just operating in a monolith? and... to the architect, are they operating in a composable system nested within another monolith (for example, you could argue the tulip platofrm itself is a monolith at a certain level).

so it makes me wonder if composable / monolithic is defined by the scope of the persona engaging int he developmen

Author: giladl
Content:
I define monolithic as system that are built on the premise of providing a business function that works the same for all. The same solution that can serve all industries, in all modalities, in all scenarios, with any equipment, and for all operators. They have to be implemented top-down with a lengthy implementation process that maps out all the requirements, scenarios and contingencies upfront. They require the adaptation of existing operational processes to what the system can support and in the way that it supports it. They provide standardized rigid hierarchical structures for representing manufacturing operations with a standard data model in a one-size fits all approach.  Monolithic systems are also designed for maintainability, meaning that they try to optimize to ease the maintenance and management of the solution by a team with specialized skillsets. 

In other words they are data model centric - define a rigid model that you have to fit your operations to. And process centric they are base on a functional decomposition of a problem domain. 

I write about it here: https://www.giladlconsulting.com/2023/11/the-decline-of-monoliths-and-jam-just.html

Author: giladl
Content:
Agreed, monoliths are good when you have a known problem domain that has small changes that you can anticipate. Its when you need agility and high flexibility - dealing with the unknown that composable shines. 

If you are making fertilizer go monolithic, as Clint Eastwood once said "If you want a guarantee, buy a toaster." 😆

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
"Profiles" are a CESMII construct. These some overlap with the OPC UA Information Models (e.g., VDMA's UA for Machinery). They can be coexist in a CESMII Smart Manufacturing Profile. The model definitions are in the CESMII / UA Cloud Library repo.

"Templates" are a Sparkplug construct. It's basically a way of defining complex data types. It's a way for a Sparkplug consumer to understand what is the full "shape" of a complex data type at initial publish before subsequent publishes of value changes. Because Sparkplug publishers are mostly Ignition in practice, templates basically declare UDTs. This is what the MQTT Engine module uses to create UDT and UDT instances within a tag provider.

Inductive Automation's demo at ProveIt imported a CESMII SM Profile as a UDT definition. Travis created a Perspective screen and a script to parse the SM Profile. Beyond this, it was the normal Cirrus Link MQTT module functionality. The UDT published out over Sparkplug with the MQTT Transmission module. Another Ignition gateway was subscribed to it with the MQTT Engine module and converted the template into a UDT. The real highlight of the demo, in my opinion, was binding Perspective components to the UDT. The cardinal sin that those involved modeling standards (e.g., OPFC, VDMA, CESMII, AMT) often make is failing to consume the model (in a meaningful way). This demonstrated that a popular application could do something useful with the data. If a consuming node doesn't do something beneficial, it makes the effort of publishing into a standard pointless. Manufacturers with problems to solve are not interested in an academic exercise of parsing standard data structures someone else defined. They don't want to map in and out of standard for the sake of standards. They want to tap in ecosystems, re-use, and not reinvent the wheel.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: HighByte's modeling is technology and standard agnostic. It's portable. Model defintions are importable as JSON structures either programmatically or as files. Up until recently, model definitions could be imported from third party solutions like Azure DTDL (now WoT) and Element Analytics' Element Unify. More commonly, users elect to consume structured data, validate or reshape/remodel, and "project" the schema to destination system. Incoming complex data examples include OPC UA Structure Data Types, Sparkplug Templates, AVEVA PI AF Assets, database tables, complex JSON returned in APIs, MTConnect, etc. It can also create "schema" in destination systems (e.g., Sparkplug Templates, PI AF Assets, AWS IoT SiteWise, data lake, data warehouse, database, Ignition tag provider). It's also possible to build pipelines to publish values and schema metadata separately (e.g., values in a narrow table, catalog in a wide table). There is flexibility on how to handle data that is not modeled, partially modeled, or already modeled.

Content:
> some infrastructure for sharing them
- the Cloud Library is just that. It works like DNS, in cascading layers. OPC runs a top level one with all the committee-created Companion Specs (including VDMA's machine building blocks)
- CESMII runs one "down stream" of that, that inherits from OPC, but includes "cloud sourced" Profiles that are open source and contributed by the community. @Travis Cox loaded one of those into Ignition during his demo last week.
- Organizations can run their own that is "down stream" (or ignores) the higher two, and use it as a way to enforce standards across all of their tools (in the same way an Enterprise may filter public DNS and/or add their own DNS records)

Author: mparris
Content:
These are the types of questions I deal with when connecting to APIs today:

1) what is the IP address/hostname to connect
2) what protocol does it support? (http, other?)
3) what encoding does it expect? (JSON, other?)
4) what endpoints are made available?
5) what functions do those endpoints support?
6) how are those endpoints formatted/organized?
7) what useful information is made available through the endpoint?
8) do the answers to the above satisfy what I need done?

Then assuming yes to #8, then it's get to work:
a) connect to application
b) translate protocol if needed
c) translate encoding if needed
d) configure consumer to point to correct endpoint
e) script consumer to use the endpoint correctly
f) convert structure/formatting of data for consumer
g) map the useful information into the application for use



**Below is what I would like it to get to:**
1) what is the IP address/hostname to connect
2) what endpoints are made available?
3) what useful information is made available through the endpoint?
4) do the answers to the above satisfy what I need done?

Then assuming "yes" to #4 above, get to work:

b) map the useful information into the application for use

Author: daan9328
Content:
A little late,  fantastic discussion on monoliths vs. composability.

Related “hot take” from  DoorDash: Microservices are technical debt: https://youtu.be/LcJKxPXYudE

Doordash moved from a monolith to microservices during COVID. Their development team grew so much and so many changes had to be made at the same time, that it was just too many people stepping on each other. Massively increased required deployment planning (release trains) and generally became kind of a nightmare as a bug in one teams code required everyone’s changes to roll back etc.

They really had no choice but to decouple the teams aggressively. They got short-term productivity from MSA,  allowing teams to develop fast without having to bother coordinating with other teams.

DoorDash (Matt) argues they also incurred a debt, because it negatively impacted the productivity of future teams. Example: You want to roll out a new feature and now that requires a change to microservices A, B and C and  suddenly there is all THAT coordination. Very much in line with your points @Zach E  and @RickBullotta   that MSA  increases dependency issues / add complexity (just in different ways than a monolith).

I really like Matt's take because 1)  He focuses on developer productivity as the core deciding factor, 2) points out that monoliths are harder when things need to change often / are made by many people.

Both sound very relatable in a manufacturing environment. The plant environment often changes and you want to deblock operators trying to respond to / solve for  their unique issues. I’m sure there’s a version of a monolith that could handle that, but moving to a composable/MSA-like model is probably easier at least in the short-term. And you pay the piper later 😊

(I do see your point Zach that in a start-up  / smaller scale phase monoliths might actually allow you to be more nimble to change stuff quickly and consistently. Just gets harder with size)

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
It's best to make decisions about technology platform decisions in the context of the problems you seek to solve. If your org does not have experience or competency working with data warehouses, I would recommend taking a step back. Microsoft vs Snowflake vs X is probably not the appropriate question to be asking right now. 

"Because Microsoft" might be an acceptable answer for undifferentiated workloads that narrow the decision criteria. This is easy for some things like infrastructure where there might be legacy investments, incumbent/migrated licensing, or hiring/staffing/outsourcing reasons. For something like an enterprise data platform, it's more complicated. There will be more time/effort put into it. There is a lot more building involved. Depending on the use cases and problems being solved, the differences between solutions may feel a lot more noticeable.

I would argue Microsoft is probably the least mature in the data warehousing / data lake space. They've done a lot of pivoting in the past ten years or so. The infrastructure and storage services (e.g., Blob, ADLS, ADLS2) were a decent start and Power BI was already well adopted, but everything in between has kind of been a miss. Azure SQL Warehouse, Synapse, and Data Factory were poorly received. Many preferred to run open-source tooling or use third-party commercial offerings or run in other cloud ecosystems altogether (e.g., AWS S3+Redshift, GCP BigQuery). Anecdotally, I saw MS shops have better luck augmenting SQL Server with Alteryx, Tibco, Informatica, etc back then. MS had to partner and go-to-market with Databricks as a stop gap. There were so many disappointments with Synapse that many won't consider leaving Azure Databricks for native MS services again. Others dislike the lack of continuity in product strategy and investment.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: This is not to say "don't use Fabric", but rather don't rely on "because Microsoft". Many orgs have gotten burned going in blind with the previous MS solutions. For those where Power BI is the center of everything, Fabric has seemed like a major improvement. Some are concerned about cost. Some are concerned about openness and the Microsoft-specific compute required to accomplish certain tasks. In isolation, the data engineering community seem to find Fabric limiting and less complete, but what they want may not necessarily be what’s best for their org. Almost everyone seems to agree that Databricks, Snowflake, and the open-source tools are more mature solutions.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: If I had to carve up the enterprise data platform market, it would be by generation. The first generation would be the legacy database players like Microsoft and Oracle. OLAP schema, columnar storage, and in-memory tech augmented their capabilities as traditional databases. Second generation would be cloud solutions like Amazon Redshift and Google BigQuery. They really figured out parallel processing and distributed columnar storage. The infrastructure complexity was significantly reduced. Think DBA-friendly without requiring storage specialists. These solutions have evolved to be more flexible/elastic and are still relevant today. Third generation solutions include Snowflake and Databricks. Fabric is a late entrant. It’s a nice vision for MS that complements Power BI and its AI strategy, but it’s a question if they can execute. Through overhauling, BigQuery has caught up. The problem with GCP is they don’t “eat their own dog food” as a company. Their ecosystem, while well thought in some corners, is less complete overall and has gaps in continuity. AWS is more complete and extensible but complex. It's the most builder friendly. Redshift has improved and is now “serverless”, but can take more work to optimize. Snowflake made the data warehouse truly elastic and simple to manage. They designed it from the ground up to run efficiently on commodity services in the public cloud. It’s very SQL focused and is intuitive for teams migrating from a traditional data warehouse. Databricks made Apache Spark and everything around it lot easier to use for enterprise. It is bring-your-own-storage and is little more engineer-friendly than IT-friendly. Earlier in their history, Databricks and Snowflake were complementary. There are some orgs that use both together. Over time, the two solutions are becoming more similar. Databricks has been adding more capabilities to support warehousing workloads. Snowflake has been adding more capabilities for compute and data processing.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: The good news is that there are options. Even if you’re a Microsoft shop, you can run solutions like Databricks and Snowflake on Azure. They can be funded with Azure credits. They can run in or peer with your Azure VNet and fit into your security strategy. Even better, the solutions are relatively easy to test out. The best approach would be to gather a list of use cases, datasets, and integrations for testing. Try out Fabric and Snowflake and anything else. Discover where the platforms work best for your team and the problems they need to solve.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
No prob. It sounds like a lot is going on.

If Power BI and Fabric are the center of gravity for your other workloads, then it makes sense to continue using it. Why are you asking about Snowflake then? Is there something that Fabric is not addressing? The thing that most people seem to like about Snowflake is that it's intuitive and the tooling is pretty complete. The UX helps with scaling adoption.

Snowflake is normatively a data warehouse and originated that way, but it can be used like a data lake. Architecturally, it's basically distributed compute on top of distributed columnar object storage. It can be used with external storage (Azure Blob) and its catalog can be exposed to external query engines. It does necessarily require duplicating the data.

As a matter of semantics, I personally would not consider Ignition as DataOps. It's an application platform with integration capabilities. Connectors + Tag Organization + Scripting != DataOps. Those are ad-hoc data transformations to exchange data with SAP.  Integrations? Yes. DataOps? No. DataOps is a collaborative data management practice.

Yeah, if you're concerned about cost and don't need the low latency, consider alternatives to MQTT for ingestion. You pay a premium to use methods that wrap Azure RTI / Event Hubs for ingestion. They require more compute. If your access patterns can tolerate it, you can gain a lot of efficiencies batching the data and loading it in the bulk through storage. Or, you can take hybrid approach of having a few "hot" pipelines for use cases that require it and going warm/bulk for everything else. In practice, what local operations build in a SCADA and what line of business users need in an enterprise data platform don't always match up. Business users may not necessarily use all the process control constructs like tags and UDTs and their transitions. They might prefer to see an aggregation of them or just specific events. Optimizing the delivery of the data can do wonders.
